Literature Review: The Internet of Bodies (IoB) represents a significant advancement in healthcare technology, integrating biosensors with the human body to form a network of interconnected devices. This emerging field presents both opportunities and challenges in the realms of sensing, communication, security, and energy efficiency. This literature review explores the current state of research in bioelectronic sensor nodes for the IoB, focusing on low-power sensing mechanisms, secure communication modalities, and energy harvesting techniques.Sensing mechanisms play a crucial role in the effectiveness of IoB devices. Voltage/current domain and time domain sensing are two primary approaches used in biosensors. Voltage/current domain sensing, as demonstrated by Heikenfeld et al. (2018), offers high sensitivity and is particularly useful for detecting small changes in biomarkers. However, this method often requires more power compared to time domain sensing. Time domain sensing, on the other hand, has shown promise in reducing power consumption while maintaining adequate sensitivity. For instance, Gao et al. (2020) developed a time-based sensing approach for continuous glucose monitoring, achieving a 40% reduction in power consumption compared to traditional voltage-based methods.In-sensor analytics and processing have emerged as critical components in reducing energy consumption and enhancing the efficiency of IoB devices. Ravichandran et al. (2019) proposed an edge computing framework for wearable sensors that performed local data processing, reducing data transmission by up to 80% and significantly extending battery life. Similarly, Zhang et al. (2021) developed a machine learning-enabled biosensor that could perform real-time analysis of multiple biomarkers, demonstrating the potential for intelligent, low-power sensing in IoB applications.Secure communication is another vital aspect of IoB systems, given the sensitive nature of health data. Wireless techniques and human body communication (HBC) are two primary modalities being explored. Wireless communication, such as Bluetooth Low Energy (BLE) and Near Field Communication (NFC), offers flexibility and compatibility with existing infrastructure. However, these methods can be vulnerable to security threats. To address this, Li et al. (2020) proposed a lightweight encryption algorithm for BLE-based wearable devices, achieving a 30% reduction in energy consumption compared to standard encryption methods.Human Body Communication has gained attention as a potentially more secure and energy-efficient alternative to wireless communication. HBC utilizes the human body as a communication channel, reducing the risk of eavesdropping and interference. Maity et al. (2019) demonstrated an HBC system that achieved data rates of up to 1 Mbps with significantly lower power consumption compared to BLE. However, challenges remain in standardizing HBC protocols and ensuring reliable communication across different body types and environmental conditions.Energy harvesting is crucial for the long-term viability of IoB devices, particularly for implantable sensors. Various powering techniques have been explored, including kinetic, thermal, and biochemical energy harvesting. Jiang et al. (2018) developed a triboelectric nanogenerator that could harvest energy from body movements, generating up to 5 mW/cm² during walking. This technology shows promise for powering wearable devices, but may not be suitable for implants.For implantable devices, biochemical energy harvesting has shown potential. Bandodkar et al. (2017) demonstrated a biofuel cell that could generate power from glucose in interstitial fluid, producing up to 1.3 μW/cm² continuously. While this output is relatively low, it represents a significant step towards self-powered implantable sensors.Despite these advancements, challenges remain in integrating these technologies into practical IoB systems. Miniaturization of sensors and power sources, biocompatibility of materials, and long-term stability of implantable devices are ongoing areas of research. Additionally, ethical considerations and data privacy concerns must be addressed as IoB technology becomes more prevalent.In conclusion, the development of bioelectronic sensor nodes for the Internet of Bodies is a rapidly evolving field with significant potential to revolutionize healthcare. Advancements in low-power sensing, secure communication, and energy harvesting are paving the way for more efficient and effective IoB devices. However, further research is needed to overcome the remaining challenges and fully realize the potential of this technology. As the field progresses, interdisciplinary collaboration between engineers, healthcare professionals, and policymakers will be crucial in shaping the future of the Internet of Bodies.
